Take steps to restore the combat readiness of your ships as soon as possible. Ships at zero combat readiness continue to be in danger of suffering accidents, unless they're already being repaired.

items, control-click to add/remove maximum amount.
%s can be built at any colony, while a %s can be found as salvage in the abandoned systems outside the core worlds.
Item goes over maximum order value
Putting blueprints into production requires a colony with %s (industry). Production quality can be improved by acquiring a %s (item).
You can still view the blueprints you've acquired, but orders to begin production will have no effect.
Maximum number of credits worth of production that can be put on this order.
The maximum order value is %s, but you only have %s credits available.
Total value of the current custom order.
Industrial production your colonies can divert to handle custom equipment orders. Based on each colony's production of the "

Production capacity is also limited by the availability of credits. If your net monthly income is negative, production will be reduced if you do not have enough credits on hand to cover the shortfall.
Production costs are deducted from your monthly income on the month that the items are delivered to the designated gathering point.
Total value of your current custom order. If an order's value exceeds the production capacity, it will take several months to fulfill. Larger items may also take longer to finish.
Custom-produced ships, weapons, and fighter LPCs will be delivered to this colony near the end of each month and placed in storage.
Will also receive an additional quantity of supplies, fuel, and crew, based on the cost of the order.
items, control-click to add/remove maximum amount.
Click to add/remove one item, shift-click to add/remove
Left-click to remove, right-click to add.
Mouse over icon for detail about the item.
Fighter name. Mouse over the icon for a detailed tooltip with its stats.
Fighter type - bomber, interceptor, heavy fighter, etc.
Prioriziting a fighter will make it more likely to be used by your faction's fleets.
The originator of the design (such as a corporation or a faction), or, for more common designs, its general classification.
%s can be built at any colony, while a %s can be found as salvage in the abandoned systems outside the core worlds.
A balanced composition with an adequate number of escorts for the larger ships.
A large number of officers with high-level training.
A large number of officers with the best possible training.
Carriers dominate the composition of any combat force.
Carriers make up the majority of a combat force.
Carriers usually make up about half of a combat force.
Few carriers, if any, are found in a combat force.
Few officers, with slightly better training.
Few phase ships, if any, are found in a combat force.
Few warships, if any, are found in a combat force.
Fleet size is at base level.
How much fleet size is favored as part of the faction's fleet doctrine.
How much ship quality is favored as part of the faction's fleet doctrine. Affects the average number of d-mods and the probability of high-quality weapons being available.
How much the number and quality of officers is favored as part of the faction's fleet doctrine.
More focus on larger ships, with fewer frigates mixed in.
Mostly frigates and destroyers, with few larger ships.
Mostly larger ships, with as many capitals as possible, at the expense of smaller escorts.
Mostly smaller ships, but without as much focus on frigates.
No doctrine setting advocates the employment of timid officers, but they may occasionally be found for hire.
Personality type of ship captains. Affects officers for the fleets created by your faction, as well as ships without officers, including the ones in your fleet. Does not affect officers you've hired.
Phase ships dominate the composition of any combat force.
Phase ships make up the majority of a combat force.
Phase ships usually make up about half of a combat force.
Preference for more smaller ships, or fewer larger ones.
Putting blueprints into production requires a colony with %s (industry). Production quality can be improved by acquiring a %s (item).
Ship hull and weapon quality increased by %s.
Ship hull and weapon quality is at base level.
Ships that rely on a fighter contingent to perform in combat.
Ships that rely on a phase cloak for defense.
Ships that rely on standard weapons, shields, and armor to perform in combat.
Usually at least some carriers as part of a combat force.
Usually at least some phase ships as part of a combat force.
Usually at least some warships as part of a combat force.
Warships dominate the composition of any combat force.
Warships make up the majority of a combat force.
Warships usually make up about half of a combat force.
Without these, your colonies will use barely-spaceworthy junk exported by other factions. The "typical" fleet composition shown reflects this.
You can still view the blueprints you've acquired, but prioritizing them will have no effect.

Mouse over icon for detail about the item.

Production cost does not include outfitting the ship with weapons and fighters - the cost for those is charged separately when the ships are delivered, and does not count against the monthly production capacity.
Production cost includes outfitting the ship with weapons and fighters. Uses the best ship production quality from your colonies, and assumes a maximum "ship quality" doctrine setting.
Ship will not be outfitted with weapons and fighters.
Uses the best ship production quality from your colonies, and assumes a maximum "ship quality" doctrine setting.
Left-click to toggle whether the item is prioritized.
Mouse over icon for detail about the item.
. The growth penalty increases with colony size.
The following contributing factors were identified:
The hazard rating results in a %s upkeep multiplier, and
The hazard rating results in a %s upkeep multiplier.
The net monthly income for this colony is %s.
The net monthly upkeep for this colony is %s.
Factors that can affect population growth:
For a size %s colony, this translates into a %s monthly growth rate.

The population growth rate is the percentage, per month, that a colony will progress towards a size increase. If the rate is negative, progress will be lost, but colony size will not be reduced even if progress reaches zero. The primary driver of colony growth is immigration.
This colony has reached its maximum size.
Colony size determines the base income and upkeep from all industries and structures, and the base production level for industries like Farming and Mining.
Colony size is an approximate measure of the population level. A colony one size larger has many times the population.
It also affects the strength and number of patrols and military fleets launched by the colony.
Post-Collapse, lacking easy access to both population and resources, the maximum size a colony can reach in a reasonable time is %s.
A colony with high accessibility is able to import and export more goods, and can claim a greater market share for any commodities it produces and exports.
Market share of exports multiplied by %s
Other imports and exports limited to %s units
Same-faction imports and exports limited to %s units
The same-faction export bonus does not increase market share or income from exports.
Can be bought for %s and sold for %s per unit, assuming a batch of %s units traded.
Market share of exports multiplied by %s
Other imports and exports limited to %s units
Same-faction imports and exports limited to %s units
The same-faction export bonus does not increase market share or income from exports.

Having more than the maximum number results in a stability penalty for all your colonies, while having less results in a stability bonus. The penalty or bonus is %s for each colony over or under the limit.
Number of colonies under your personal control, and the maximum. Does not include colonies governed by administrators or AI cores.
Colonies under administrator control do not count for or suffer from this penalty.

Having more than the maximum number of colonies under your personal control results in a stability penalty for all your colonies, while having less results in a stability bonus. The penalty or bonus is %s for each colony over or under the limit.
Stability penalty or bonus (if any) based on the number of colonies under your personal control.

Ship type - warship, carrier, phase ship, or civilian.
The originator of the design (such as a corporation or a faction), or, for more common designs, its general classification.
Cost to produce a hull of this ship type. The hull will not have any weapons or fighter LPCs mounted.
Production cost. Does not include outfitting the ship with weapons and fighters.
Production cost. Includes outfitting the ship with weapons and fighters.
The cost of weapons and fighters installed on the ship will be deducted once it's produced and does not count against the monthly production capacity.
Prioriziting a weapon will make it more likely to be used by your faction's fleets.
The originator of the design (such as a corporation or a faction), or "Common" for designs found in use throughout the Sector.
Weapon name. Mouse over the icon for a detailed tooltip with its stats.
Weapon type - ballistic, energy, or missile.

Warning: Low system RAM remaining, may result in poor performance due to possible pagefile usage
Warning: Maximum JVM RAM allocation exceeds 8 GB, this is not recommended as it may result in poor game performance!

This will exit to the main menu WITHOUT saving your current game.
This will overwrite your last save with the current game.
This will save a copy of your current game to a new slot, which will become the currently-active slot.
This will save your game and exit to the main menu.
Type "DELETE" to confirm you want to do this:
Starsector is running with a total conversion mod that is not used by this save. The save is extremely unlikely to load properly.
Starsector is running with mod(s) that are not used by this save. Depending on how the mod(s) are written, this may work properly or not at all.
This save is using a mod version that's a major mismatch from the one you have enabled. It is unlikely to load properly, or work once it's loaded with this version of the mod.
This save is using a mod version that's a minor mismatch from the one you have enabled. There is a possibility it may fail to load, or to work properly once loaded.
This save is using a normal mod that is no longer enabled. It is unlikely to load properly until that mod is re-enabled.
This save is using a total conversion ("TC") mod that is no longer enabled. It is extremely unlikely to load properly until that mod is re-enabled.
This save is using a utility mod that is no longer enabled. However, it should work properly without that mod being enabled.
Which mods this game was ever saved with, last saved with, and which mods are currently enabled.
EEE, MMM d, yyyy, hh:mm a
Around 50% fewer star systems compared to normal.
Cooler stars, fewer planets, less minerals. More habitable worlds.
Different constellations may have different ages.
Hotter stars, more planets, more mineral resources. Fewer habitable worlds.
More balanced mix of stars and planets.
Buying or selling enough of a commodity at a market will influence its economic availability, based on the total number of units bought or sold recently.
The current transaction will increase the availability of %s by %s.
The current transaction will not affect the availability of %s.
The current transaction will reduce the availability of %s by %s.

The impact depends on the current availability level - i.e. if the availability is high, it will take more units bought or sold to influence it - and will be adjusted if commodity availability changes.
Shows detailed information about this colony, including the industries and structures present, and supply and demand for various commodites.
Since you've been denied docking clearance, and the circumstances make any underground parties unwilling to contact you, you're currently unable to trade here.

Only show planets that you have full survey data for.
Only show planets that you do not have full survey data for.
Only show planets and stations that are controlled by a faction.
Only show planets that are not controlled by any faction.
Only show planets that are not controlled by any faction and are not in a star system that is claimed by a faction that cares about maintaining its territorial integrity.
Only show unsurveyed planets that you're able to run a full survey on, given the hazard rating and survey cost.

Sort by market size. Applies to inhabited planets and stations only.
Sort by distance from your fleet, in light-years.
Sort by planet class, which roughly corresponds to the general desirability of the planet for colonization.
Sort by relative cost to run a full survey, based on the survey resource requirements. Requires a preliminary survey to determine.
Values highlighted in red indicate a cost that exceeds your current resources.
Sort by the hazard rating. Requires at least a low-orbit preliminary survey to determine.

Location relative to your fleet. The minimap is centered on your fleet's location.

Approximate credit value of spoils for each marine unit assigned to the objective. For objectives that require a fixed number of marine units, the total approximate value.
Approximate quantity for each marine unit assigned to the objective. Can also be a credit value, and, for objectives that require a fixed number of marine units, the total approximate quantity.
How many additional days the target will be disrupted for, given the number of marine units currently assigned. Already-disrupted targets suffer less disruption from continued raids.
How many days the target is already disrupted for. Already-disrupted targets suffer less disruption from continued raids.
Shows the impact of achieving this objective with the assigned number of marine units. Generally shows the temporary deficit that will be caused by raiding a specific commodity.

Forces available to be assigned. Higher raid effectiveness allows more objectives to be targeted with a single raid. One marine unit is available for every %s raid effectiveness. The current raid effectiveness is %s and %s marine units are available.
Holding some forces in reserve will reduce the casualties suffered by your marines by %s per unit, but the reserves will not directly contribute to achieving any objectives.
Left-click on an objective to assign forces, right-click to unassign. Control or shift click to assign/unassign all forces to/from an objective.
in your fleet and the projected casualties

Projected marine casualties if the raid is carried out. Depends on the danger level of the designated objectives, as well as on other factors. Leaving some forces in reserve reduces the overall casualties.

Projected total value of all spoils from the raid. The value of some objectives, such as blueprints, is difficult to estimate due to the high variance possible. These kinds of objectives are not included in this value.
Deficit. Less available, higher danger level.
Excess stockpiles. More available, lower danger level.
Imported by the colony. Average quantity available, standard danger level.
Name or description of objective. For commodities, also indicates its availability.
Produced by the colony. Average quantity available, lower danger level.
Marine units required to achieve objective.
Number of marine units assigned to the objective. Some objectives require a fixed number of marine units to be achieved.
Maximum number of industries, based on the size of a colony and other factors.
Structures such as spaceports or orbital stations do not count against this limit. Colonies that exceed this limit for any reason have their stability reduced by %s.
Build time, in days. Until the industry or structure finishes construction, it will not provide any of its benefits, but any demand for commodities starts immediately.

Whether it's an industry or a structure. The number of industries at a colony is limited, based on its size.

Does the name require a "the" in front of it, where appropriate?

Now that you have planet-based or otherwise static assets, you'll need to set up your faction's name and flag. You can always change these later, by clicking on your faction's name in the colony screen.
Should "a" or "an" be used with the name, where appropriate?
Should "is" or "are" be used with the name, where appropriate?
What ship name prefix should be used? Can be empty.
Select a flag to represent your faction
A "free port" has reduced stability, but increased accessibility. It also benefits from gradually increasing population growth as its reputation spreads.
If free port status is revoked, the bonus population growth will be reset to its starting value on exiting this screen.
Unlike normal markets, a free port gets income from smuggled exports.
For this colony, the total incentive cost is %s per month.

Hazard pay and other financial incentives or investments meant to drive increased immigration to this colony. The growth rate bonus is equal to the colony's hazard rating based penalty to immigration, plus an additional %s points. Each point of growth costs %s per month.
Added population growth towards increased colony size
Already invested funds can be withdrawn at %s of the original value.
The approximate cost of %s additional population growth is %s.

The effect of growth incentives will drop off gradually over the course of several cycles, with larger colonies taking longer to work through the full incentive amount. Note that even with incentives, the growth rate is not guaranteed to be positive, especially if stability is low.
When a colony's size increases, any leftover funds will be applied to further growth.

The maximum arc the shields can cover.
When raised, shields gradually fan out to cover their full arc. Shields with a larger maximum arc take longer to open up fully.
A phase cloak generates hard flux while active.
However, it will prevent the zero-flux engine boost from activating, and will increase the time it takes for already-built-up flux to dissipate.
If the maximum flux capacity is exceeded, the ship will overload and de-cloak.
Keeping shields down unless they're absolutely necessary is key to improving both mobility and damage output.
Shields generate some soft flux when they're raised even when they're not taking damage.
The amount of flux is usually less than the ship's dissipation, so this will not cause flux to build up on its own.
Turning on a phase cloak generates some hard flux.
A low "shield flux per damage" value indicates a more efficient shield capable of absorbing more damage.
Absorbing damage with shields generates "hard" flux, which can not be dissipated while shields are turned on.
Shields have different efficiency ratings, generating a different amount of flux per point of damage absorbed.
When a ship exceeds its flux capacity due to taking shield damage, it will overload and become unable to use weapons or defenses until it recovers.
A ship with a high flux capacity is able to absorb more damage with shields and pour out more weapons fire during a window of opportunity, increasing its short-term effectiveness.
Firing weapons and using shields generates flux.
It may also be more vulnerable while waiting for the built-up flux to dissipate, especially since higher flux capacity often comes at the expense of the dissipation rate.
A ship with higher flux dissipation gets rid of the built-up flux more quickly, increasing its combat effectiveness over the long term.
Absorbing damage with shields generates "hard" flux, which can not be dissipated while shields are turned on.
Firing weapons and using shields generates flux.
Flux is dissipated at double the normal rate while actively venting.
Each vent costs %s ordnance point and increases dissipation by %s flux per second.
Each capacitor costs %s ordnance point and increases flux capacity by %s.
The maximum speed of this ship under normal combat conditions.
When a ship's flux is at zero and it's not generating any flux, it receives a bonus of %s to top speed, as well as a boost to turn rate and acceleration.

Damage that gets through armor and shields gets applied to the hull. Taking hull damage can cause weapons and engines to become temporarily disabled, and is likely to result in casualties among the crew.
Once hull reaches zero, the ship becomes disabled, though it may be recoverable (by the winner) after the battle ends.
Armor reduces the damage taken by a percentage that depends on the relative strength of the armor compared to the amount of damage, and blocks damage from getting through to the hull.
Damage applied in a single hit is much more effective at stripping away armor than the same damage distributed over multiple hits.
Each hit reduces the amount of armor that remains in the affected area, making each successive hit more and more powerful.
The "hit strength" of beam weapons - which do not score separate hits, but deal damage continuously - is based on their damage/second.
The effective armor value can not go below %s of its original value, even if it's stripped away entirely, and damage reduction from armor can not exceed %s.
Firing most weapons (except, generally, missiles) generates flux.
Some weapons can fire more and build up more flux over the short term. This value reflects the sustained flux generation that accounts for the rate at which weapons recharge.
This is the total flux per second that continuously firing all the weapons on the ship will generate.
Must be docked at a market to perform ship restoration.

When the number of ships in your fleet exceeds %s, numerous logistical challenges manifest themselves, increasing the entire fleet's maintenance supply use by %s for every ship above the maximum.
Most of these effects are based on the deployment points value of the ships, which is equal to the ship's base deployment recovery cost, prior to modification by factors such as d-mods.

Flux per second generated by the sustained firing of this group. Some weapons are capable of higher burst fire - due to ammo, charges, and similar mechanics; this value does not reflect the resultant higher initial flux generation.
Whether this weapon is assigned to this group. Shift-click to assign all weapons of the same type.
If a weapon group is left empty, it can still be selected, allowing all of the ship's weapons to autofire.
There are a maximum of %s possible weapon groups.
%s: all weapons will fire as rapidly as possible while the fire button is held down.

%s: each press of the fire button will fire the selected weapon and switch to the next weapon in the group. Selecting the group repeatedly will also switch to the next weapon. If the fire button is held down, weapons will alternate firing at a rate that will approximately fire them as they are ready to fire, if possible.
Click row to cycle between fire modes.
If a weapon group is on %s, the weapons fire independently and the group's fire mode has no effect.
The %s fire mode is useful for missiles or other weapons where fine-grained control over the volume of fire - or of which weapons fire - is needed.
AI-controlled ships will turn autofire on and off based on the tactical situation and this setting has no impact.
If a weapon group is on autofire, the weapons fire independently and the group's fire mode has no effect. A weapon group will not autofire while it is selected.
Whether each group has %s turned on when combat starts. Autofire for weapon groups can also be toggled on and off during combat.

to turn off your shields and let the flux dissipate.
%s to turn on your shields again and let the enemy keep firing at you.
(By the way - you can pause and unpause the game at any time by pressing
(So, even if you're not taking any damage on the shields, keeping them off will let you put out more firepower.)
As you can see, it's not good - when flux maxes out from shield hits, your ship overloads.
Congratulations! You've completed the basic combat tutorial.
Each ship also has a special system - an active ability it can perform. For the Hammerhead, it's an Accelerated Ammo Feeder that greatly increases the rate of fire for ballistic weapons.
Fire your Assault Chainguns (group 1) for a bit and watch how they build up flux, then continue when you're ready.

Firing most weapons (except for missiles) generates flux. Your ship has a limited flux capacity, and managing what you use it on is key to survival. You can see your current flux level on the info display in the lower left corner of the screen.
Flux gained from firing weapons is called soft flux, and can dissipate while the shields are up.
Flux gained when shields absorb damage is called hard flux and only dissipates while the shields are off - so, you can't keep shields up indefinitely while taking damage.
Fortunately, you can set any weapon group on autofire, making the weapons identify and attack targets on their own.
Good. As you can see, you've now been flanked by a pair of Lasher-class frigates.
Good. Now, let's see what happens if you keep your shields on under fire for too long.
Guided missiles require a target. By default, they'll lock on to the enemy nearest to your cursor when you fire.
Hover over the enemy ship and press %s to target it.
It'd be nice to shoot these down - we've got some point-defense lasers just for that. But, it's almost impossible to manually target all the incoming missiles.
Just sit tight and let them get a few volleys off.
Moving the mouse around pans your view. You can also use the mouse wheel to zoom in and out.
Note how the lasers switch to attacking the missiles as soon as they're launched - point defense weapons will prioritize targeting missiles.
Now that the ship is no longer overloaded, flux is back to dissipating at a normal rate.
Now, let's see how the shields hold up under fire.
Press %s and %s to turn, %s and %s to accelerate forward or back, and hold %s to bring your ship to a halt. Give this a try, and press "Continue" when you've got the hang of it.
Press %s to activate the Accelerated Ammo Feeder and fire the Assault Chainguns (group 1) to see its effect.
Press %s to enable autofire for the point-defense lasers in group 3. Make sure you have a different group selected - selecting an autofiring group will result in a manual override of its controls.
Regular weapons will not target missiles automatically.
Shields generate flux continuously while they're up, and generate even more flux every time they absorb damage.
Some ship systems have limited uses, some generate flux, some have a cooldown - and some use a combination of those.
The Accelerated Ammo Feeder must cool down before it can be used again.
The enemy ship has stopped firing, but your flux level still isn't going down!

The flux from firing these dissipates almost as quickly as it's generated. Different ships and ship loadouts dissipate flux at different rates, and so can support varying amounts of weapons effectively.
The notch on the flux bar indicates your hard flux level.
There's now an enemy ship - an Enforcer-class destroyer - at your 12 o'clock. Its weapon and maneuvering systems are disabled.
They're going to start launching missiles at you. Fortunately, these missiles aren't very effective vs well-armored ships.
Wait for the oveload to end.
While the ship is overloaded, it can't fire or raise shields, dissipates flux very slowly, but can still maneuver normally.
While venting, your ship can't fire or use shields, so you generally only want to do it when it's safe.
You can also lock onto a specific enemy to ensure missiles go after it, and to see more information about it.
You can also vent flux to dissipate it at double the normal rate.
Your flagship for this tutorial is a Hammerhead class destroyer. First things first - let's learn how to get it moving.
Your ship will turn towards your mouse pointer while you strafe, so keep the cursor on top of the target.
to re-open the command UI, if necessary (and don't forget to unpause!)
will show a quick video feed that only lasts for as long as the key is held down.
(If you only have one ship, it's deployed automatically.)
(To pan the view around, right-click and drag, or move the mouse to the edge of the screen. You can toggle the command UI on and off by pressing
) and wait for your ships to secure the objectives.
... and press the "Transfer Command" button, then wait for the shuttle pod to take you to the new flagship.
... and right-click on the Comm Relay.
... and select "Avoid" from the list of available assignments.
... and select "Eliminate" from the list of available assignments.
A nearby frigate is automatically assigned to the task - that's what the arrow on the map indicates.

An assignment appropriate to your selection, and what you right-clicked on, was created - in this case, another "Capture". You can also assign specific ships to existing assignments by selecting them and right-clicking on the assignment.
At the start of a battle, you have to decide what ships to deploy. Recovering after a deployment costs supplies, so you usually don't want to just deploy everything.
Congratulations! You've completed the fleet command tutorial. Feel free to experiment with other assignments to explore the tactical options they offer, and see if you can win this battle.
Creating an assignment costs a command point, but also opens the command channel. While it's open, giving orders is free.
Go ahead, try it out - press the "Show Video Feed" button.
Good. Now, let's create some assignments for our ships to carry out.
Good. Now, let's order our ships to focus on the enemy destroyer.
Good. Some of the the ships in your fleet will now engage the enemy destroyer, and the rest will try to hold the objectives, with all avoiding the enemy cruiser.
It's the only target left, so they'll naturally do that anyway, but giving an "Eliminate" order will also make them more aggressive.
Let's transfer command to the Hammerhead, so you can pilot it yourself, and play out the rest of the battle.
Now that the orders are locked in, let's unpause (press
Since this is the tutorial and supply costs aren't an issue, let's deploy everything.
The bonuses these provide are modest, but they add up, especially given that if you don't hold them, the enemy will.
The enemy cruiser is tough, but relatively harmless - we'd like our ships to focus on the more dangerous enemy first.
The first thing we want to do is capture some objectives - locations especially suited for the deployment of nav buoys, sensor arrays, or comm relays.
The tutorial will resume once both objectives are captured.
To deploy ships, press the "Reinforcements" button in the upper right.
You can also exit the feed by pressing
You can also manually assign a ship to perform a task. Select one of the other frigates...
You can also press ESCAPE to leave the tutorial.
You can exit the feed at any time by pressing ESCAPE.
You can keep an eye on what each ship is doing by clicking on it and selecting "Show Video Feed".
You might have noticed that you're not directly controlling a ship at the moment. This can happen if you don't deploy your flagship, or if your flagship is destroyed.
Hold C to slow down and stop near the buoy.
Press R to bring up a target overlay that gives you more information about the ship.
Press ~ to toggle the weapon firing arc display.
Press V to vent flux from your ship.
Move your ship away from this billboard! Use WASD to pilot.
The fighters may try to run after you destroy a couple - don't let them get away!
Here are some asteroids for company, and target practice.
Tip: holding SHIFT while pressing A or D will make your ship strafe. Your ship will auto-turn towards the mouse while strafing.
You have completed the tutorial. Press ESCAPE to go back to the main menu, or fly around a bit if you like.
Press 1 to switch to the Assault Chainguns and destroy the enemy ship.
Press 2 to switch to the Sabot missiles and keep firing until the enemy shields are down.
As you can see, your ship is not building up flux despite the shields being under fire.
Be careful - when a ship is disabled, the explosion deals damage to all nearby ships, except for fighters.
EMP damage does not affect shields, armor, or hull - but it can quickly disable enemy weapons and engines.
Energy damage deals 100% of its listed damage to everything.
Excellent, the enemy ship is taking hull damage now. Let's finish it off!
Excellent. Now, maneuver behind the enemy ship to disable its engines. You'll need to take out more than half to cause a total flameout.
Fire enough Sabots at the enemy ship to overload its shields.

Fragmentation damage deals only 25% to armor and shields, but usually costs little flux and has a high base DPS value, making it effective vs exposed hull, or lightly armored, unshielded targets - like missiles and fighters.
Great work! With the shields down and an overload in progress, the enemy ship is vulnerable. The next step is to bring down its armor.
High explosive damage deals 200% to armor, but only 50% to shields.
Let's take another look at shields. Turn on your shields and sit tight for a moment - you'll be attacked with beam weapons.
Make sure you're far enough away to avoid damage. About a ship's length should be enough.
Non-EMP weapons can also disable engines and weapons, but EMP weapons bypass armor and get the job done faster.
Ships receive an engine boost - a bonus to top speed and maneuverability - when their flux level and flux generation are at zero.
Since the enemy ship has its shields up, let's start off by firing some Sabot missiles at it - they are extremely effective at bringing down shields.
Some weapons also deal EMP damage in addition to their normal damage type.
Switch to your Assault Chainguns and punch through the armor. To break through faster, focus your fire on one spot.
That ship is now a sitting duck - it won't be able to maneuver at all until the engines are back online.
The engine boost is particularly important for larger ships, which have a much lower top speed without it.
This is because beam weapons generate soft flux when hitting shields.

This may make them seem weak - but remember that this flux still needs to be dissipated, leaving that much less flux dissipation to power weapons. Beam weapons are also very efficient and need little flux to fire.
Travel through the nebula in front of your ship, noting how your ship moves faster when the shields are down.
Turning shields on - even without taking any damage - is enough to cancel the bonus.
We've already gone over the basics of using weapons in the previous tutorial. Now, let's take a look at picking the right weapon for the job.
Welcome to the advanced combat tutorial. Let's get started!
Your Ion Cannons deal lots of EMP damage (and little else). Switch to the Ion Cannons and disable some of the weapons on the Enforcer.
Your flagship is still the same Hammerhead, but the point defense lasers have been swapped out for Ion Cannons - more on those later.
*Per unit prices assume buying or selling a batch of %s units. Each unit bought costs more as the market's supply is reduced, and each unit sold brings in less as demand is fulfilled.

A limited production chip that allows a carrier's nanoforges to produce fighters, replacement parts, and related ordnance.
Fighters that return to a carrier - for example, after a bombing run - are relaunched quickly and do not require the full replacement time.

The replacement rate gradually goes down while the carrier's fighter wings are on average not at full strength, and is slowly regained otherwise. It goes down more slowly while fighters are ordered to regroup.
This wing is built into the hull - it can not be removed and does not cost any ordnance points.

Required to deploy ships. The side more able of engaging on its terms gets more points. This is determined at the start of the engagement by the presence of capable officers in command of combat-ready ships. The number and size of the ships involved is also a small contributing factor.

The following resources are required for your fleet to run a full survey of
A colony that's unstable for too long runs the risk of becoming decivilized.
A more stable colony produces larger fleets with well-maintained ships.
A stable colony is also more resistant to raids and invasions, and has less black market activity.
The colony's stability is a measure of the strength of the local government and its ability to effectively muster and leverage the resources of the colony.
The strength of the ground defenses affects the effectiveness of raids and other ground operations against the colony. It also increases the amount of fuel required to bombard it.

Cancelling assignments does not cost command points, and cancelling all assignments will allow your fleet to engage the enemy at will.
Command points are required to create assignments and give direct orders to your fleet. Once an order is given, all other orders are free for a few seconds while the command frequency remains open.
Ordering a full assault will cancel all assignments and also make your ships engage very aggressively. Cancelling a full assault requires a command point.

If your forces inflict sufficient losses on the enemy, you will be able to disengage without being pursued after the conclusion of this engagement, even if your forces retreat and the enemy wins the engagement.

Bonus experience doubles your experience gain until it's used up; %s bonus experience means "enough to earn an extra
Some of the bonus experience is granted immediately, while the remainder is gained on reaching the maximum level.

The amount of bonus experience depends on the deployment recovery cost of the ship - less expensive ships grant more bonus experience. Recovering ships that were already in your fleet always grants full bonus experience.
